entries.entry_description: Cerulean Dragons are lofty and distant, valuing knowledge and relishing trickery.

overview_table_group_data.title: Preferred Prey
overview_table_group_data.content: Mountain and Prairie fauna; deer, elk, horses

entries.entry_description: Crimson Dragons are notably egotistical, even among dragons.  They prefer to enslave and berate mortals of all kinds, demanding their reverance and zealous servitude.  They typically pillage seeking great treasures and materials to adorn their lair in their own honor.

overview_table_group_data.title: Preferred Prey
overview_table_group_data.content: Savanha and Desert fauna; camels, bison, gazelles, elephants

entries.entry_description: Gemstone Dragons are mysterious and inscrutinable.  They live the vast majority of their lives underground, carving massive subterranean lairs with sprawling networks of caves.

Indigo Dragons are especially fearsome, preying on coastal civilizations and seafaring vessels alike.  They greatly prefer to enslave aquatic mortals, but even that is a rare occurence.  Indigo Dragons are voracious and aggressive, likely due to the large number of comparable threats that the seas contain compared to other environments.  They typically decorate their lair with sunken vessels and the corpses of their mightiest foes.

overview_table_group_data.title: Preferred Prey
overview_table_group_data.content: Aquatic and Coastal faunu; fish, whales, bison

entries.entry_description: Alabaster Dragons are arguably the most sadistic of the dragons.  They enslave mortals on occasion, but never retain them for long.  The brutally cold temperatures inside an Alabaster Dragons lair makes certain of that.  Alabaster Dragons find great joy in watching their subjects slowly freeze to death, adorning their lair with frozen statues and inset displays of their defeated foes and prior minions encased in ice.

overview_table_group_data.title: Preferred Prey
overview_table_group_data.content: Arctic fauna; yetis, polar bears, mammoths, seals

entries.entry_description: Umbral Dragons are detached and rationale, only showing or acting on emotion in exceptionally rare circumstances.  Their motivations are largely unknown, and they are often found meddling with mortal affairs from the inside.  It is not uncommon for an Umbral Dragon to set two things that are at odds with each other in motion, leaving many confused about their true motivations.

overview_table_group_data.title: Preferred Prey
overview_table_group_data.content: Urban fauna; rats, alligators, horses, people

entries.entry_description: Stygian Dragons are often mistaken for demons, both in their appearance and behaviors.  They are famously unpredictable, resentful of authority structures that they are not at the top of, and creatively cruel.  Many of them enslave demons and mortals alike, along with any other hapless being that might be unfortunate enough to meet them.  They often adorn their lairs with unique expressions of suffering, often including custom made mechanisms or living testaments.  Stygian Dragons are widely considered the most undesireable, and for good reason.

Viridian Dragons are revered by those who value nature, and are often incorporated in pagan religions.  Viridian Dragons keep to themselves and guard their chosen territory with relentless cunning and brutality.  They have been commonly known to allow nomads passage through their territory, and even allow hunters to stalk their territory if they are deemed worthy and respectful of the nature around them.  In many ways, Viridian Dragons are literal guardians of nature itself, behaving as ethical stewards of their land while living off of it.  Stories of Viridian Dragons that have saved herds of deer from raging dire crocodiles or feral therianthropes are not uncommon, with the dragon leaving the herd intact afterwards in most cases.  Their fearsome appearance and large menacing horn often provokes conflict with those who are familiar with their nature, especially mercenaries or soldiers who are unknowingly trespassing.

overview_table_group_data.title: Preferred Prey
overview_table_group_data.content: Forest fauna; deer, cattle, wolves, rabbits

entries.entry_description: Cobalt Dragons are masters of knowledge and secrets, commonly revered in academic symbolism.  They often lend aid to nations and organizations known to possess large libraries, humbling requesting access in return.  The lairs of Cobalt Dragons are the envy of learned mages across all lands, containing tomes acquired and meticulously maintained across thousands of years in some cases.  Many Cobalt Dragons are knowledgeable mages themselves, but they typically abhor the thought of using magic for violence.

overview_table_group_data.title: Preferred Prey
overview_table_group_data.content: Mountain and Prairie fauna; deer, elk, horses

entries.entry_description: Gold Dragons are often seen as the Kings of Dragons, and heavily associated with regality and nobility.  Gold Dragons are known for swift and vengeful retribution when an act of cruelty or barbarism is committed in their presence.  This extends across the entirety of their territory, sometimes creating small micro-societies within their territory that are governed only by the local dragon's justice.

overview_table_group_data.title: Preferred Prey
overview_table_group_data.content: Savanha and Desert fauna; camels, bison, gazelles, elephants

entries.entry_description: Copper Dragons are the least interested in mortal affairs of the metallic dragons, only intervening when the most catastrophic of events or injustices occur.  They keep to themselves in underground lairs, often collecting historical remnants of nations they have interacted with so as to preserve pieces of their culture.  While bored by the grand machinations of mortals, Copper Dragons are known to possess a deep longing for intimate and challengin conversation.  The mortals who do happen across Copper Dragons, both in their lair and elsewhere, are either dismissed as irrelevant and spoken with as briefly as possible to obtain the desired information or obsessively analyzed, questioned, and challenged in a civil battle of words and wits.

Bronze Dragons are extremely financially inclined and logistically focused.  They find a great deal of joy in tracking cargo shipments and reviewing warehouse stock levels.  Bronze Dragons usually procure treasure from sunken vessels and return it to the rigthful owner with fees for their service removed, allowing them to amass small fortunes that they then use to invest in seafaring cargo shipment companies.  You would be hard pressed to find a merchantile coster with seafaring vessels that doesn't have the financial backing of a Bronze Dragon.  While Bronze Dragons do value civility and order as any Metallic Dragon would, they hold a remarkably potent resentment for pirates.  Gold Dragons are widely considered the most brutal and vengeful of the Metallic Dragons, but accounts of Bronze Dragons razing pirate vessels certainly makes them a competitor for that title.

overview_table_group_data.title: Preferred Prey
overview_table_group_data.content: Aquatic and Coastal faunu; fish, whales, bison

entries.entry_description: Silver Dragons are the most interested in mortal affairs of all the dragons.  They often seek to offer council to rulers in government and judges in courts of law.  Silver Dragons utterly despise those who corrupt the legal system, having been known to publicly execute government officials who fail to uphold the oath they took.  Their lairs are often adorned with documents and organizational symbols, such as house crests or the statue that presided over a courthouse.  The treasure they value most of all are legislative documents from nations past, often spending hours poring over them and coming up with new ideas to present to the nobles they advise.

overview_table_group_data.title: Preferred Prey
overview_table_group_data.content: Arctic fauna; yetis, polar bears, mammoths, seals

entries.entry_description: Brass Dragons are the most eccentric of the Metallic Dragons by a considerable margin.  They often insert themselves in mortal societies with a series of rotating interests, the most stable of which being art.  Brass Dragons fill their lairs with the most unique and potent works of art they can find, often treasuring their newest pieces most dearly.  They constantly redecorate and cycle through their collection to adorn their lair in different combinations from year to year, sometimes forgetting about pieces they own that are buried in the back of their storage chambers.  There have been relics from cultures thousands of years old found in Brass Dragon hoards, and they are just as prone to give it away as they are to defend it with their lives.  As unreliable as Brass Dragons may be, any city fortunate enough to find a Brass Dragon setting up permanent residence within its walls is sure to find itself much wealthier as it becomes a central hub of culture and expression.
